docs.lead_paragraph: As my colleague Michael Shear explained on Friday, history shows that running a write-in campaign for office is not easy, particularly for candidates whose names voters might find hard to spell.

docs.lead_paragraph: Do Republicans in Washington think they can capture the Senate seat in West Virginia? A new $1.2 million advertising buy in the state certainly seems to suggest they do.

docs.lead_paragraph: Overview | If the economic recession officially ended 15 months ago, why is the poverty rate still rising? In this lesson, students learn about the correlation between job growth and poverty. They investigate how national trends in economics, labor and commerce are playing out in their area and then go into the community to photograph and compile evidence. They present their findings in a class-wide project.

headline.main: Onward and Upward? Documenting Local Economic Conditions

docs.abstract: Lesson Plan | Investigating how national poverty and jobless rates and other economic indicators are reflected in the community.
docs.snippet: Lesson Plan | Investigating how national poverty and jobless rates and other economic indicators are reflected in the community.

byline.original: By SHANNON DOYNE and HOLLY EPSTEIN OJALVO

docs.lead_paragraph: For young Americans with no health insurance, Thursday was an important day: those younger than 26 were able to join their parents' plans under the recently enacted health care overhaul. (Previously, children were dropped from their parents' policies at 19, or 23 if they were full-time students.) Young people make up the largest group of uninsured Americans, although they are healthier and cheaper to insure. And they are much less likely to vote. Still, in many states with high rates of uninsured young adults, providing health coverage is not at the forefront of political campaigns. Below, the areas of the country with high rates of uninsured, and how health care is playing out as an issue in those areas:
docs.abstract: A New York Times graphic looks at the areas of the country with high rates of uninsured, and how health care is playing out as an issue this election cycle.
docs.snippet: A New York Times graphic looks at the areas of the country with high rates of uninsured, and how health care is playing out as an issue this election cycle.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline.main: The Perennial Quest to Lower Health Care Spending

docs.abstract: Absent some miracle, the political constraints against reducing health care spending mean that the nation is likely to rely in the years ahead on rationing more and more of health care by income class, an economist writes.
docs.snippet: Absent some miracle, the political constraints against reducing health care spending mean that the nation is likely to rely in the years ahead on rationing more and more of health care by income class, an economist writes.
